DataElement.preferredDefinition: The name of the pre-existing condition.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic respiratory disease manifested as difficulty breathing due to the narrowing of bronchial passageways.

Concepts.definition: A chronic respiratory disease manifested as difficulty breathing due to the narrowing of bronchial passageways.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Coronary artery disease

(dye-a-BEE-teez) A disease in which the body does not properly control the amount of sugar in the blood. As a result, the level of sugar in the blood is too high. This disease occurs when the body does not produce enough insulin or does not use it properly.

Concepts.definition: A metabolic disorder characterized by abnormally high blood sugar levels due to diminished production of insulin or insulin resistance/desensitization.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Abnormally high blood pressure.

Concepts.definition: Blood pressure that is abnormally high.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area. (Dorland, 27th ed)

Concepts.definition: Gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Angina pectoris which has not recently changed in frequency, duration or intensity. Stable angina pectoris is relieved by rest or administration or oral, sublingual or transdermal antianginal medications.

Concepts.definition: Angina pectoris which has not recently changed in frequency, duration or intensity. Stable angina pectoris is relieved by rest or administration or oral, sublingual or transdermal antianginal medications.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Failure of the heart to pump a sufficient amount of blood to meet the needs of the body tissues, resulting in tissue congestion and edema. Signs and symptoms include shortness of breath, pitting edema, enlarged tender liver, engorged neck veins, and pulmonary rales.

Concepts.definition: Failure of the heart to pump a sufficient amount of blood to meet the needs of the body tissues, resulting in tissue congestion and edema. Signs and symptoms include shortness of breath, pitting edema, enlarged tender liver, engorged neck veins, and pulmonary rales.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: STROKE
Rheumatoid/osteoarthritis
Fibromyalgia
History of nonmelanoma skin cancer
History of other malignancy
HYPERLIPIDEMIA
Hypertriglyceridemia
Previous colon resection

A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder affecting the heart or the vessels (arteries, veins and lymph vessels).  Representative examples of non-neoplastic cardiovascular disorders are endocarditis and hypertension.  Representative examples of neoplastic cardiovascular disorders are endocardial myxoma and angiosarcoma. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder affecting the heart or the vessels (arteries, veins and lymph vessels). Representative examples of non-neoplastic cardiovascular disorders are endocarditis and hypertension. Representative examples of neoplastic cardiovascular disorders are endocardial myxoma and angiosarcoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Inflammation of a joint or a state characterized by inflammation of joints.

Concepts.definition: An inflammatory process affecting a joint. Causes include infection, autoimmune processes, degenerative processes, and trauma. Signs and symptoms may include swelling around the affected joint and pain.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No Value Exists

Concepts.definition: A neoplastic or non-neoplastic condition affecting the kidney. Representative examples of non-neoplastic conditions include glomerulonephritis and nephrotic syndrome. Representative examples of neoplastic conditions include benign processes (e.g., renal lipoma and renal fibroma) and malignant processes (e.g., renal cell carcinoma and renal lymphoma).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lung disease

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Active Infection, less than or equal to 30 days
No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having a high amount of body fat (body mass index [BMI] of 30 or more).

Concepts.definition: Having a high amount of body fat (body mass index [BMI] of 30 or more).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Liver Disease
Infectious Disease, Chronic

Human immunodeficiency virus. Species of LENTIVIRUS, subgenus primate lentiviruses (LENTIVIRUSES, PRIMATE), formerly designated T-cell lymphotropic virus type III/lymphadenopathy-associated virus (HTLV-III/LAV). It is acknowledged to be the agent responsible for the acute infectious manifestations, neurologic disorders, and immunologic abnormalities linked to the ACQUIRED IMMUNODEFICIENCY SYNDROME.

Concepts.definition: The virus isolated and recognized as the etiologic agent of AIDS. HIV-1 is classified as a lentivirus, a subtype of retroviruses.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.: The principal sterol of all higher animals, distributed in body tissues, especially the brain and spinal cord, and in animal fats and oils. (MSH98)

Concepts.definition: An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

An animal sterol found in the body tissues (and blood plasma) of vertebrates. It can be found in large concentrations within the liver, spinal cord, and brain. Cholesterol is an important component of the membranes of cells, providing stability. It is the major precursor for the synthesis of vitamin D, of the various steroid hormones, including cortisol, cortisone, and aldosterone in the adrenal glands, and of the sex hormones progesterone, estrogen, and testosterone.  Cholesterol also has an important role for the brain synapses as well as in the immune system.  In conditions featuring elevated low density lipoproteins (LDL), cholesterol often forms plaque deposits in the walls of arteries, a condition known as atherosclerosis, which is a major contributor to coronary heart disease and other forms of cardiovascular disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Increased pressure in the eyeball due to obstruction of the outflow of aqueous humor.

Concepts.definition: Increased pressure in the eyeball due to obstruction of the outflow of aqueous humor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Digestive Disease
A melancholy feeling of sadness and despair.

Concepts.definition: A melancholy feeling of sadness and despair.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disease or condition that persists or progresses over a long period of time.: Pain in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve.: A common, severe type of vascular headache often associated with increased sympathetic activity, resulting in nausea, vomiting, and light sensitivity.

Concepts.definition: Usually used to describe a condition that is persistent and long standing.
Pain in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve.
A common, severe type of vascular headache often associated with increased sympathetic activity, resulting in nausea, vomiting, and light sensitivity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder resulting from loss of function or tissue destruction of an organ or multiple organs, arising from humoral or cellular immune responses of the individual to his own tissue constituents. It may be systemic (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus), or organ specific, (e.g., thyroiditis).

Concepts.definition: A disorder resulting from loss of function or tissue destruction of an organ or multiple organs, arising from humoral or cellular immune responses of the individual to his own tissue constituents. It may be systemic (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus), or organ specific, (e.g., thyroiditis).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Inflammation of the pancreas.

Concepts.definition: Inflammation of the pancreas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Inflammation of the lining of the stomach.

Concepts.definition: Inflammation of the stomach.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Ulcer that occurs in those portions of the alimentary tract which come into contact with gastric juice containing pepsin and acid. It occurs when the amount of acid and pepsin is sufficient to overcome the gastric mucosal barrier.

Concepts.definition: A mucosal erosion that occurs in the esophagus, stomach or duodenum. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and bleeding.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A chronic disorder characterized by reflux of the gastric and/or duodenal contents into the distal esophagus. It is usually caused by incompetence of the lower esophageal sphincter. Symptoms include heartburn and acid indigestion. It may cause injury to the esophageal mucosa.

Concepts.definition: A chronic disorder characterized by reflux of the gastric and/or duodenal contents into the distal esophagus. It is usually caused by incompetence of the lower esophageal sphincter. Symptoms include heartburn and acid indigestion. It may cause injury to the esophageal mucosa.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Inflammation of the liver; usually from a viral infection, but sometimes from toxic agents.

Concepts.definition: Inflammation of the liver; usually from a viral infection, but sometimes from toxic agents.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disorder characterized by replacement of the liver parenchyma with fibrous tissue and regenerative nodules. It is usually caused by alcoholisms, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C. Complications include the development of ascites, esophageal varices, bleeding, and hepatic encephalopathy.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by replacement of the liver parenchyma with fibrous tissue and regenerative nodules. It is usually caused by alcoholism, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C. Complications include the development of ascites, esophageal varices, bleeding, and hepatic encephalopathy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Build-up of fatty material and calcium deposition in the arterial wall resulting in partial or complete occlusion of the arterial lumen.

Concepts.definition: Build-up of fatty material and calcium deposition in the arterial wall resulting in partial or complete occlusion of the arterial lumen.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: chronic diseases, as well as diseases and exposures associated with cancer.
